thread.title: Jobs data more of a lottery than usual
thread.title_full: Jobs data more of a lottery than usual

title: Jobs data more of a lottery than usual
text:
Thu, Sep 10, 2015, 5:46 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 4 hrs 14 mins Jobs data more of a lottery than usual AAP – 2 hours 14 minutes ago Recommend Print 
Forecasting the latest labour force figures could prove more of a lottery than normal after revisions to past data and the introduction of a government measure to get more people into the workforce. 
Economists had been expecting a more modest 6000 rise in the number of people employed when August labour force figures are released on Thursday. 
But that would have been enough to get the jobless rate to tick down to 6.2 per cent after the unexpected spike to 6.3 per cent in July. 
However, the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday issued revisions to past jobs figures to reflect more up-to-date population estimates. 
It resulted in employment growth being revised down by more than 30,000 over the past year. 
While it kept the unemployment rate at 6.3 per cent, the July employment rise of 38,500 was scaled back to 37,900. 
At the same time, Treasurer Joe Hockey has warned that the government's $6.8 billion Jobactive program may create some short-term volatility in the jobless data. 
That's because some people who were classified as not seeking work in June are now seeking work and therefore counted as part of the labour force. 
In an analysis this week, ANZ economists said it was difficult to gauge the potential size of this effect, but it does risk some permanency to the sharp jump in the jobless rate seen in July. 
Little wonder they titled their report `Australian labour force report - handle with care'. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Puerto Rico unveils austerity, reform plan to slash debt AFP
